France
Germany | language = Arabic | budget = }} '''''A Perfect Day''''' ({{lang-ar|'''يوم اخر'''}}, ''Yawmon Akhar'') is a 2005 Lebanese film directed by [[Joana Hadjithomas]] and [[Khalil Joreige]]. The soundtrack was done by the band [[Scrambled Eggs (band)|Scrambled Eggs]],[http://www.virb.com/scrambledeggs Scrambled Eggs on Virb.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025055118/http://www.virb.com/scrambledeggs |date=October 25, 2007 }} [[Soap Kills]] and others. ==Plot== Malek, a 26-year-old man who suffers from sleep disorders, is obsessed with thoughts of his ex-girlfriend Zeina. Meanwhile, his overprotective mother struggles with the disappearance of her husband, who was kidnapped more than 15 years ago during the civil war. ==Cast== * [[Ziad Saad]] as Malek * [[Julia Kassar]] as Claudia * [[Alexandra Kahwagi]] as Zeina == Music== *Scrambled Eggs: Charbel Haber, Marc Codsi, Tony Elieh,Said Elieh *[[Soap Kills]]: [[Zeid Hamdan]] & [[Yasmine Hamdan]] ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0469692|title=A Perfect Day}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060521182359/http://www.aperfectday-lefilm.com/ ''A Perfect Day'' Official website] *[http://www.hadjithomasjoreige.com/ Directors website] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QYFMIgEGnOs Trailer of the movie] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Perfect Day, A}} [[Category:2005 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Lebanese films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:German films]] [[Category:Arabic-language films]] {{2000s-drama-film-stub}} {{Lebanon-film-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Asian Centre for Human Rights''' ('''ACHR''') is an [[NGO]] (non-governmental organization) dedicated to the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the Asian. It is headquartered in [[New Delhi]], [[India]]. The '''Asian Centre for Human Rights''' seeks to provide timely and accurate information; conducts investigations, research and campaigns and lobbies about country situations or individual cases. It aims to increase the impact of human rights activists and civil society groups; provide input into international standard-setting processes on human rights; provide political, legal and practical advice. It secures cultural, social, and economic rights through rights-based approaches to international development. The centre maintains a particular focus on [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Nepal]], [[Philippines]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Bhutan]], [[Maldives]], [[Pakistan]] and [[Thailand]]
==External links==
* [http://www.achrweb.org Homepage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051228182750/http://www.undp.org/oslocentre/docs05/3665%20Booklet_heleWEB_.pdf Entry] in the [[UNDP]]'s "Guide to Civil Society Organizations working on Democratic Governance" (PDF)
{{int-org-stub}} [[Category:International organizations of Asia]] [[Category:Human rights organisations based in India]]

{{ infobox donkey | name = Asinara donkey | image = Wild albino donkeys.jpg | image_caption = Asinara donkeys | image_alt = | features = predominantly [[albinism|albinistic]] | distribution = [[Sardinia]] | altname = Asino dell'Asinara | standard = [http://www.aia.it/CMSContent/NORME%20TECNICHE%20RA_nuovo.pdf MIPAAF] | nickname = | country = Italy | group1 = | std1 = | group2 = | std2 = }} [[File:Fieracavalli 2014 - Asinara, Ragusano.jpg|thumbnail|With [[pack saddle]] at [[Fieracavalli]]]] The '''Asinara donkey''', {{lang-it|'''Asino dell'Asinara'''|italic=no}} ({{IPA-it|ˈaːzino dellaziˈnaːra}}), is a [[list of donkey breeds|breed]] of [[feral]] [[donkey]] indigenous to the island of [[Asinara]], which lies off the north-west coast of [[Sardinia]], Italy, in the [[province of Sassari]].<ref name=dad/> Most of the population is wholly or partly [[albinism|albinistic]]; the small number of grey donkeys on the island are also considered part of the population, and are probably [[heterozygous]] carriers of the albino gene.<ref name=bigi/> The Asinara donkey is one of the eight autochthonous donkey breeds of limited distribution recognised by the [[Ministero delle Politiche Agricole Alimentari e Forestali]], the Italian ministry of agriculture and forestry.<ref name=aia/> It is called ''{{lang|sc|ainu}}'', ''{{lang|sc|borricu}}'' or ''{{lang|sc|molenti}}'' in [[Sardinian language|Sardinian]].<ref name=reg/>
There are approximately 120 individuals on the island. Others are in the natural reserve of [[Porto Conte]] in [[Alghero]] and at the Istituto di Incremento Ippico at [[Burgos, Sardinia|Foresta Burgos]], and a few are raised in [[Tuscany]] and in [[Emilia Romagna]].<ref name=bigi/>
==History== The Asinara donkey probably derives from a chance mutation in the population of [[Sardinian donkey]]s abandoned on the island by the inhabitants when they were forcibly evacuated from it following the law of 28 June 1885, under which Asinara was to be transformed into a [[lazaret]] and [[penal colony]]. It is also possible that the breed descends from white donkeys imported from Egypt in the 19th century by the Duca dell'Asinara.<ref name=bigi/>
==See also== * [[List of Italian donkey breeds]]
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=aia>[http://www.aia.it/CMSContent/NORME%20TECNICHE%20RA_nuovo.pdf Norme tecniche: Allegato 2 a D.M. 9742 del 7 maggio 2012] (in Italian). Ministero delle Politiche Agricole Alimentari e Forestali. p. 18. Accessed September 2013.</ref>
<ref name=bigi>Daniele Bigi, Alessio Zanon (2008). ''Atlante delle razze autoctone: Bovini, equini, ovicaprini, suini allevati in Italia'' (in Italian). Milan: Edagricole. {{ISBN|9788850652594}}. p. 158–59.</ref>
<ref name=dad>[http://dad.fao.org/cgi-bin/EfabisWeb.cgi?sid=0b1613ebf16355cf65f6a05b9a65fe25,reportsreport8a_50000085 Breed data sheet: Asino dell'Asinara / Italy]. Domestic Animal Diversity Information System of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Accessed September 2013.</ref>
<ref name=reg>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722053658/http://www.sardegnaturismo.it/index.php?xsl=87&s=4504&v=2&c=3174&t=1 White donkey]. Regione Autonoma della Sardegna. Archived 22 July 2011.</ref>
}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox military installation | name = Briconet Redoubt | native_name = Ridott ta' Briconet | location = [[Marsaskala]], [[Malta]] | image = Briconet Redoubt - part used as police station.jpeg | image_size = 300px | caption = View of Briconet Redoubt | map = Briconet Redoubt map.png | image_mapsize = 300px | map_caption = Map of Briconet Redoubt | type = [[Redoubt]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|51|56.2|N|14|33|54.8|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} | ownership = [[Government of Malta]] | controlledby = Police Department
[[Scout Association of Malta]] | open_to_public = No | built = 1715 | used = | builder = [[Knights Hospitaller|Order of Saint John]] | materials = [[Limestone]] | height = | condition = Intact | battles = | events = | garrison = [[Żejtun]] Regiment }} '''Briconet Redoubt''' ({{lang-mt|Ridott ta' Briconet}}), also known as '''Marsaskala Redoubt''' ({{lang-mt|Ridott ta' Marsaskala}}) or the '''Vendôme Entrenchment''' ({{lang-mt|It-Trunċiera ta' Vandomu}}), is a [[redoubt]] in [[Marsaskala]], [[Malta]]. It was built in 1715 by the [[Knights Hospitaller|Order of Saint John]] as one of a series of coastal fortifications around the Maltese Islands. Until recently, the redoubt was used as a police station. ==History== Briconet Redoubt was built in 1715 as part of the first building programme of coastal batteries and redoubts in Malta. It formed part of the defences of Marsaskala Bay, which also included the large [[Saint Thomas Tower|St. Thomas Tower and Battery]] and the now-demolished [[Żonqor Tower]].{{cite book|last=Guillaumier|first=Alfie|date=2005|title=Bliet u Rħula Maltin – Volume 2|language=Maltese|publisher=Klabb Kotba Maltin|isbn=9993239402|pages=154–155, 955}} [[File:Briconet_Redoubt.jpeg|thumb|left|The redoubt viewed from the rear]] Briconet Redoubt's structure is typical of most other coastal redoubts built in Malta. It consists of a pentagonal platform having short flanks, and a rectangular [[blockhouse]] sealing off the gorge. Unlike other redoubts, the gorge and flanks have high boundary walls pierced by musketry loopholes. These were built to defend the redoubt from a landward attack, since it is overlooked by high ground.{{cite web|title=Marsascala police station|url=http://anecdotesfrommalta.blogspot.com/2009/05/marsascala-police-station.html|website=anecdotesfrommalta.blogspot.com|date=12 May 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620191553/http://anecdotesfrommalta.blogspot.com.mt/2009/05/marsascala-police-station.html|archivedate=20 June 2016}} Construction of the redoubt cost 768 scudi. These were paid by the knight Giovanni Battista Briconet, and the redoubt was named in his honour. The redoubt was initially garrisoned by militia from [[Żejtun]],{{cite web|title=Fortifications|url=http://marsaskala.lc.com.mt/fortifications/|website=Marsaskala Local Council|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316102719/http://marsaskala.lc.com.mt/fortifications/|archivedate=16 March 2016}} and it was armed with two cannons. ==Present day== [[File:Briconet Redoubt and modern building.jpeg|thumb|right|View of the redoubt with one of the modern structures visible]] Today, Briconet Redoubt is still intact and in good condition, being one of the best preserved redoubts in Malta. A few modern modifications have been made, such as the opening of a small doorway on one of its faces to enable access from the modern road. The redoubt is surrounded by modern buildings, including Marsaskala's parish church,{{cite web|title=Marsaskala|url=http://www.mydestination.com/malta/sights/138452/marsaskala|website=mydestination.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620191535/http://www.mydestinationmalta.com/sights/marsaskala|archivedate=20 June 2016}} which have completely blocked its relation with the sea. Until the early 21st century, Briconet Redoubt was used as the Marsaskala Police Station,{{cite news|last1=Chetcui|first1=Joe|title=The Malta Independent Online|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2006-10-29/letters/the-malta-independent-online-164341/|work=[[The Malta Independent]]|date=29 October 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304110355/http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2006-10-29/letters/the-malta-independent-online-164341/|archivedate=4 March 2016}} until this was moved to an irregular structure in a garden next to the church.http://www.illum.com.mt/ahbarijiet/qrati_u_pulizija/40042/marsascala_tispia_mingajr_gassa_talpulizija#.W1JN7hrRahA Today, the redoubt is a Grade 1 national monument and it is also listed on the [[National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]].{{cite web|title=Marsacala Redoubt|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1424.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629144904/http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1424.pdf|archivedate=29 June 2015|date=28 June 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Briconet Redoubt}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150629144904/http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1424.pdf National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands] {{redoubts}} [[Category:Redoubts in Malta]] [[Category:Castles and fortifications of the Knights Hospitaller]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1715]] [[Category:Defunct police stations in Malta]] [[Category:Marsaskala]] [[Category:Limestone buildings in Malta]] [[Category:National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]] [[Category:18th-century fortifications]] [[Category:1715 establishments in Malta]] {{Malta-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox Political post |post = Chief of Defence |native_name = {{lang-nl|Chef Defensie}}
{{lang-fr|Chef de la Défense}} |body = |flag = |flagsize = 125px |flagcaption = |insignia = |insigniasize = 110px |insigniacaption = |imagesize = 165px |image = Marc Compernol (cropped).jpg |incumbent = General [[Marc Compernol]] |incumbentsince = 13 July 2016 |member_of = |department = |reports_to = [[Minister of Defence (Belgium)|Minister of Defence]] |nominator = |appointer = |termlength = |formation = 28 February 1958 |first = Lieutenant-General [[Jacques de Clarcq]] |deputy = |website = }} The '''Chief of Defence''' ({{lang-nl|Chef Defensie}}, {{lang-fr|Chef de la Défense}}), abbreviated as '''[[Chief of Defence|CHOD]]''', is the professional head and commander of the [[Military of Belgium|Belgian Armed Forces]]. He is the highest official within the [[Ministry of Defence (Belgium)|Ministry of Defence]] and the Chief of the Defence Staff. He reports directly to the Minister of Defence and is responsible for advising the Minister, for the implementation of defence policy and for the administration of the department. The current Chief of Defence is [[General]] [[Marc Compernol]], since July 2016. ==Chiefs of Staff (1958−present)== {{Officeholder table start | showorder = y | showimage = y | officeholder_title = Chief of Staff | showtermlenght = y | showparty = n | showdefencebranch = y | showref = n }} {{Officeholder table | order = 1 | image = blank.png | military_rank = Lieutenant General | officeholder = [[Jacques de Clarcq]] | officeholder_sort = de Clarcq, Jacques | officeholder_note = | born_year = | died_year = | term_start = 28 February 1958 | term_end = 30 November 1959 | timeinoffice = {{ayd|1958|02|28|1959|11|30}} | defence_branch = {{army|Belgium}} }} {{Officeholder table | order = 2 | image = blank.png | military_rank = Lieutenant General | officeholder = Baron [[Charles Paul de Cumont]] | officeholder_sort = de Cumont, Charles Paul | officeholder_note = | born_year = 1902 | died_year = 1990 | term_start = 9 December 1959 | term_end = 30 June 1963 | timeinoffice = {{ayd|1959|12|09|1963|06|30}} | defence_branch = {{army|Belgium}} }} {{Officeholder table | order = 3 | image = blank.png | military_rank = Lieutenant General | officeholder = [[G. {{refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox song | name = Cool Vibes | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Vanilla Ninja]] | album = [[Blue Tattoo (album)|Blue Tattoo]] | A-side = Cool Vibes | released = June 20, 2005 | format = [[CD Single]], [[music download|digital download]], [[Maxi single]] | recorded = 2005 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Gothic rock]], [[hard rock]], [[pop rock]], [[Symphonic metal]] | length = 3:00 | label = [[Bros Music]] | writer = [[David Brandes]],
Jane Tempest (Petra Brändle),
[[Bernd Meinunger|John O'Flynn]] | producer = [[David Brandes]] | prev_title = I Know (Unplugged) | prev_year = 2005 | next_title = Megamix | next_year = 2005 | misc = {{Infobox song contest entry | embed=yes | song = {{flagicon|Switzerland}} "Cool Vibes" | image = | caption = Vanilla Ninja at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]]. | year = 2005 | country = Switzerland | artist = [[Lenna Kuurmaa]],
[[Triinu Kivilaan]],
[[Piret Järvis]],
[[Katrin Siska]] | as = [[Vanilla Ninja]] | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = [[David Brandes]],
Jane Tempest | lyricist = [[Bernd Meinunger|John O'Flynn]] | place = 8th | points = 128 | place_semi = 8th | points_semi = 114 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?2005ch from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Celebrate | prev_link = Celebrate (Piero Esteriore & The MusicStars song) | next = If We All Give a Little | next_link = If We All Give a Little }} }} '''"Cool Vibes"''' was the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] entry to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]], sung by [[Estonia]]n girl band [[Vanilla Ninja]]. The song was composed by [[David Brandes]] and "Jane Tempest" (Petra Brändle), and was written by [[Bernd Meinunger]], under the [[pseudonym]] "John O'Flynn". It performed at the semi-final [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]] in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]]. It performed 19th on the night, following [[Andorra]]'s [[Marian van de Wal]] with "[[La mirada interior]]" and preceding [[Croatia]]'s [[Boris Novković]] and "[[Vukovi umiru sami]]". At the close of the voting the song received 114 points, placing 8th. At the final of the contest, Vanilla Ninja performed 22nd on the night, following [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]'s [[Feminnem]] with "[[Call Me (Feminnem song)|Call Me]]" and preceding [[Latvia]]'s [[Valters & Kaža|Walters and Kazha]] and "[[The War Is Not Over]]". At the close of the voting the song received 128 points, placing 8th out of 24 countries. It was succeeded as Swiss representative by [[Six4one]] with "[[If We All Give a Little]]". ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" |- !Chart (2005) !Peak
position |- | [[Austrian Singles Chart]][http://austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Vanilla+Ninja&titel=Cool+Vibes&cat=s Austrian Singles Chart] |align="center"|58 |- | [[German Singles Chart]][http://www.officialcharts.de/showitem.asp?interpret=Vanilla+Ninja&titel=Cool+Vibes&cat=s&country=de German Singles Chart] |align="center"|42 |- | [[Estonian Singles Chart]] |align="center"|3 |- | [[Swiss Singles Chart]][http://hitparade.ch/showitem.asp?interpret=Vanilla+Ninja&titel=Cool+Vibes&cat=s Swiss Singles Chart] |align="center"|17 |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2005}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2005]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Switzerland]] [[Category:Songs written by David Brandes]] [[Category:Songs written by Bernd Meinunger]] [[Category:Sony Music Entertainment singles]] [[Category:2005 songs]] {{Switzerland-stub}} {{Estonia-stub}} {{2000s-song-stub}}

{{Infobox Former Country |native_name = {{native name|li|Graofsjap Häör}}
{{native name|nl|Graafschap Horn}} |conventional_long_name = County of Horne |common_name = Horne | |continent = Europe |region = Low Countries |era = Middle Ages |status = County |empire = Holy Roman Empire |government_type = Feudal County | |event_start = |year_start = 920 |date_start = |event_end = [[French Revolutionary Wars: Campaigns of 1795|Annexed by France]] |year_end = 1795 |date_end = |event1 = [[Prince-Bishopric of Liège|Personal union]] |date_event1 = 1568 |event_post = [[Concordat of 1801|Concordat]] |date_post = 10 September 1801 | |p1 = |s1 = Meuse-Inférieure |flag_s1 = Flag of France.svg |image_coat = Blason Comtes de Hornes.svg |image_map = Locator Lordship of Horne (1350).svg |image_map_caption = Lordship of Horne (1350) |capital = [[Horn (Netherlands)|Horn]] |latd=51 |latm=14 |latNS=N |longd=5 |longm=57 |longEW=E |common_languages = [[Limburgish]] ([[Dutch language|Dutch]]) |religion = Roman Catholicism }} [[File:County of Horne 1789.jpg|thumb|300px|The County of Horn in the 18th century]] [[Image:Thorn, Horn, Kessenich.PNG|thumb|300px|Map showing the Imperial Abbey of Thorn, the County of Horne and the barony of Kessenich]] [[File:HORN-002.JPG|thumb|250px|Castle Horn]] '''Horne''' (also ''Horn'', ''Hoorn'' or ''Hoorne'') is a small historic [[county]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] in the present day [[Netherlands]] and [[Belgium]]. It takes its name from the village [[Horn (Netherlands)|Horn]], west of [[Roermond]]. The residence of the counts of Horne was moved from Horn to [[Weert]] in the 15th century. After the execution in 1568 of [[Philip de Montmorency, Count of Hoorn|Philip de Montmorency]] who died without male heirs, the [[Prince-Bishopric of Liège|Prince-Bishop of Liège]], as suzerain of Horne, was declared the direct lord and new count. The bishops ruled the county in personal union. Horne maintained its own laws and customs as well as its financial autonomy. The county included the communes of Neer, Nunhem, Haelen, Buggenum, Roggel, Heythuysen, Horne, Beegden, Geystingen and Ophoven.Bulletin de la Commission centrale de statistique, Brussels, 1857, vol. 7, p. 136. It was suppressed in 1795, when it was [[French Revolutionary Wars: Campaigns of 1795|occupied by the French]], and it became part of the French département [[Meuse-Inférieure]]. ==Rulers of Horne== ===Lords of Horne=== * Engelbert de Hurne, * Engelbert de Hurnen, * Henry van Horn, † 1196 * William, * Engelbert, * Gerhard van Horn * William I., † 1264/65, * Engelbert van Horn, 1212/64 * William II., † 1300/1301, * William III., † 1301, * Gerhard I., † 1330, * William IV., † 1343, * Gerhard II., X 1345, * William V., 1344/57 * William VI., † 1417, * William VII., † 1433, ===Counts of Horne=== * Jacob I., † 1488, * Jacob II., † 1530, * Jacob III., X 1531, * John, † 1540 * [[Philippe de Montmorency]] * The prince-bishops of Liège, 1568-1795 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * Detlev Schwennicke, [[Europäische Stammtafeln]] Band XVIII (1998) Tafel 62ff und Band XIV (1991) Tafel 122 * [https://nassauterhaar.weebly.com/ House of Nassau-Ter Haar Official Website] {{Lower Rhenish–Westphalian Circle}} {{coord missing|Netherlands|Belgium}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Horne, County Of}} [[Category:Limburg (region)|County of Horne]] [[Category:History of Limburg (Netherlands)|County of Horne]] [[Category:1795 disestablishments in the Holy Roman Empire]] [[Category:States and territories established in the 920s]] [[Category:Counties of the Holy Roman Empire]] [[Category:920 establishments]] [[Category:10th-century establishments in the Holy Roman Empire]] {{Netherlands-hist-stub}} {{Belgium-hist-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat V F-4 → Intelsat 504 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1982-017A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1982-017A|title=INTELSAT 5 F-4|publisher=National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | SATCAT = 13083 | mission_duration = 13 years | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] bus | manufacturer = [[Ford Aerospace]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|1012|kg|lb}} | launch_mass = {{convert|1928.2|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|March 5, 1982, 00:23|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 36|LC-36A]] | launch_contractor = | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|November 1995}} | orbit_epoch = March 5, 1982 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|6547|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|42132|km}} | orbit_inclination = 24.1 degrees | orbit_eccentricity = 0.57914 | orbit_period = 629.8 minutes | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]]
4 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat V'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat V F-3]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat V F-5]] }} '''Intelsat 504''', previously named '''Intelsat V F-4''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1982, it was the fourth of fifteen [[Intelsat V]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat V series was constructed by [[Ford Aerospace]], based on the [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat V F-4 was part of an advanced series of satellites designed to provide greater telecommunications capacity for [[Intelsat]]'s global network. The satellite was deactivated on November 1995. The satellite was successfully launched into space on March 5, 1982, at 00:23 UTC, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], Florida, United States. It had a launch mass of 1,928 kg. The Intelsat 504 was equipped with 4 [[Ku-band]] transponders more 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] [[transponder]]s for 12,000 audio circuits and 2 TV channels. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1982}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1982]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{Infobox organization |name = IREN Kenya |image = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = |formation = |status = [[Non-profit organization]] |purpose = advocates for [[free market]] economics for the development of [[Africa]] |location = |region_served = Kenya |membership = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |budget = |website = [http://www.irenkenya.com/ IREN Kenya] }} The '''Inter Region Economic Network''' (IREN) is a [[non-governmental organization]] based in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], which advocates [[free market]] economics for the development of [[Africa]]. Its director is [[James Shikwati]]. IREN's key focus areas include targeted events, training, [[research]], [[consultancy]], communication and its flagship magazine: The African Executive - published in English every Wednesday.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://irenkenya.com/modules/about_us/index.php?section=about_us&title=About+IREN |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-03-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130924185606/http://irenkenya.com/modules/about_us/index.php?section=about_us&title=About+IREN |archivedate=2013-09-24 |df= }}</ref>

{{Infobox Airline |airline = Kayala Airline |logo = |logo_size = 120 |fleet_size = 4 |destinations = 8 |IATA = XY |ICAO = KNE |callsign = - |parent = [[National Air Services]] (NAS) |company_slogan = There's a spirit in the air |founded = July 2005 |ceased = 1 April 2009 |headquarters = [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi-Arabia]] |key_people = |hubs =
*[[Jeddah]]-[[King Abdulaziz International Airport]] *[[Riyadh]]-[[King Khalid International Airport]]
|website = www.kayala.com }} [[File:Kayala Airlines Airbus A319 KvW.jpg|thumb|Kayala Airlines Airbus A319.]] '''Kayala Airline''' (previously called '''Al Khayala''') was an [[airline]] based in [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]]. Kayala was a privately owned premium class airline operating domestic and international scheduled as well as charter services. Its main base was [[King Abdulaziz International Airport]], Jeddah, with a hub at [[King Khalid International Airport]], [[Riyadh]].[[Flight International]] 27 March 2007 ==History== The airline started operations on 16 July 2005 and was wholly owned by Saudi aviation company [[National Air Services]]. Until 6 May 2008, the airline was known as ''Al-Khayala''.[http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20080506073544 Kayala Airlines reached new heights with a new look and Jeddah-Dubai route re-launch - Middle East News] On 1 April 2009, bankruptcy was declared and all operations were ceased.[http://www.ch-aviation.ch/aircraft.php?search=set&airline=HG&al_op=1 Airlines] == Destinations == At May 2008, the following destinations were served:[http://www.kayala.com/en/tripplanning/schedule.html Kayala Airline] ;Saudi Arabia *[[Jeddah]] ([[King Abdulaziz International Airport]]) *[[Riyadh]] ([[King Khalid International Airport]]) ;United Arab Emirates *[[Dubai]] ([[Dubai International Airport]]) ==Fleet== The Kayala Airline fleet consisted of the following aircraft (at February 2008):[http://www.ch-aviation.ch/aircraft.php?search=set&airline=NAR&al_op=1 Aviation] *3 [[Airbus A319-112]] *1 [[Airbus A320-214]] All aircraft were operated by [[National Air Services]]. After operations ceased, the aircraft were stored. ==External links== *[http://www.kayala.com/ Kayala] *[http://www.ch-aviation.ch/aircraft.php?search=set&airline=ALK&al_op=1 Kayala Fleet] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Airlines of Saudi Arabia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kayala Airlines}} [[Category:2005 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:2009 disestablishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2005]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2009]] [[Category:Defunct airlines of Saudi Arabia]] {{SaudiArabia-transport-stub}}

[[Image:Kitenge.jpg|thumb|A typical kitenge pattern.]] [[Image:Chitenge-baby-sling.jpg|thumb|Woman carrying a baby on her back using a kitenge.]] ''For the surname, see [[Kitenge (surname)]].''
'''Kitenge''' or '''chitenge''' is an [[East Africa]]n, West African and Central African fabric similar to [[sarong]], often worn by women and wrapped around the chest or waist, over the head as a [[headscarf]], or as a [[baby sling]]. Kitenges are colourful pieces of fabric. In the Coastal area of Kenya, and in Tanzania, Kitenges often have Swahili sayings written on them.
Kitenges are similar to [[Kanga (African garment)|kanga]]s and kikoy, but are of a thicker cloth and have an edging on only a long side. [[Kenya]], [[Uganda]], [[Tanzania]], [[Sudan]], Nigeria, Ghana, Senegal, Liberia, Rwanda, and Democratic Republic of the Congo are some of the African countries where kitenge is worn.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} In [[Malawi]], [[Namibia]] and [[Zambia]], kitenge is known as ''Chitenge''. They are sometimes worn by men around the waist in hot weather. In some countries like Malawi, Chitenges never used to be worn by men until recently when the president encouraged civil servants to buy Malawian products by wearing Chitenje on Fridays.
Kitenges (plural ''vitenge'' in [[Swahili language|Swahili]]; ''zitenge'' in [[Tonga people of Zambia and Zimbabwe|Tonga]]) serve as an inexpensive, informal piece of clothing that is often decorated with a huge variety of colors, patterns and even political [[slogan]]s.
The printing on the cloth is done by a traditional [[batik]] technique. These are known as wax prints and the design is equally as bright and detailed on the obverse side of the fabric. These days Wax prints are commercially made and are almost completely roller printed. Fancy prints are roller printed with the designs being less colorful or detailed on the obverse side. Many of the designs have a meaning. A large variety of religious and political designs are found as well as traditional tribal patterns. The cloth is used as material for dresses, blouses and pants as well.
==Uses == Chitenges can be used on occasions and in many ways either symbolically or for practical reasons. Chitenges are used in different settings to convey messages. The following list demonstrates uses of the cloths.
*In Malawi, Chitenjes are customary for women at funerals. *They are used as a sling to hold a baby across the back of a mother. They can hold the baby at the front as well, particularly when breast feeding. *Chitenges are given as gifts to young women. *They are sometimes tied together and used as decorative pieces at dinner tables. *When women go to the beach, often the Chitenge is wrapped around the bathing suit for modesty or to shield cold air. *Chitenges can be framed or otherwise hung up on the wall as a decorative batik artwork.
Kitenges have also become very popular as fashion statements in urban pop culture with youth in Africa. Kitenges are incorporated in clothing items such as hoodies, trousers, and accessories such as bags.
== See also == * [[Shweshwe]] *[[African waxprints]]
==External links== *[http://artmatters.info/?p=446 Kenya’s Quest for National attire] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/content/articles/2004/10/05/features_2004_10_our_man_in_zambia_14_feature.shtml Material wealth], a BBC article about Chitenges in Zambia <!--http://www.col.org/stamp/UpTech4.pdf-->

{{Use British English|date=July 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Sir Malcolm Campbell | honorific_suffix = {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|MBE}} | image = Malcolm Campbell rc10431.jpg | image_size = | caption = Sir Malcolm Campbell circa 1935 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1885|03|11|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Chislehurst]], [[Kent]], England | death_date = {{death date and age|1948|12|31|1885|03|11|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Reigate]], [[Surrey]], England | death_cause = | resting_place = St Nicholas Church, Chislehurst, Kent, England | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[Uppingham School]] | employer = | occupation = Racing motorist, journalist | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = {{ubl|{{marriage|Marjorie Dagmar Knott
|1913|1915|end=div}}|{{marriage|Dorothy Evelyn Whittall
|1920|1940|end=div}}|{{marriage|Betty Nicory
|1945}}}} | partner = | children = {{hlist|[[Donald Campbell|Donald]]|Jean}} | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{flag|United Kingdom}} | branch = {{army|United Kingdom}} | serviceyears = 1914–1945 | rank = [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] | servicenumber = 86891 | unit = [[Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment]] }} }} [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] '''Sir Malcolm Campbell''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|MBE}} (11 March 1885 – 31 December 1948) was a British racing motorist and motoring journalist. He gained the world speed record on [[Land Speed Record|land]] and on [[Water speed record|water]] at various times during the 1920s and 1930s using [[List of Bluebird record-breaking vehicles|vehicles called ''Blue Bird'']], including a [[Grand Prix Sunbeams 1921, 1922 TT|1921 Grand Prix Sunbeam]]. His son, [[Donald Campbell]], carried on the family tradition by holding both land speed and water speed records. ==Early life and family== Campbell was born in [[Chislehurst]], Kent on 11 March 1885,{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=mVDUbCN19RY3B20K%2Fa%2BD4A&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}} the only son of William Campbell, a [[Hatton Garden]] diamond seller. He attended the independent [[Uppingham School]]. In Germany, learning the diamond trade, he gained an interest in motorbikes and races. Returning to Britain, he worked for two years at [[Lloyd's of London]] for no pay, then for another year at £1 a week. Between 1906 and 1908, he won all three London to Lakes End Trials motorcycle races. In 1910 he began racing cars at [[Brooklands]]. He christened his car ''Blue Bird'', painting it blue, after seeing the play ''[[The Blue Bird (play)|The Blue Bird]]'' by [[Maurice Maeterlinck]] at the [[Haymarket Theatre]]. Campbell married Marjorie Dagmar Knott in 1913 but divorced two years later.{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=87AdayIVHdUD18gEazu3VA&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}} Campbell then married Dorothy Evelyn Whittall in 1920 and their son [[Donald Campbell|Donald]] was born in 1921, and their daughter, Jean, in 1923.{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=vUWl8pj5KuIh25pbvLEeLw&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}} They divorced in 1940. Campbell married Betty Nicory in 1945 in Chelsea.{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=%2FSqLT2LzjwZCQJ%2Fk%2BjABlA&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}} ==Military service== At the outbreak of [[World War I]] Campbell initially enlisted as a motorcycle dispatch rider and fought at the [[Battle of Mons]] in August 1914.{{cite book |last=Calley |first=Roy |date=1 September 2014 |title=The World Water Speed Record: The Fast and the Forgotten |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?isbn=1445637987 |location=[[Stroud]] |publisher=Amberley Publishing |isbn=9781445637860 |author-link=Roy Calley}} Shortly afterwards he was commissioned as a [[Second Lieutenant]] in the 5th Battalion, [[Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment|Queen's Own (Royal West Kent Regiment)]], a [[Territorial Force]] unit, on 2 September 1914.{{London Gazette |issue=28910 |date=22 September 1914 |page=7496}} He was soon drafted into the [[Royal Flying Corps]] where he served as a ferry pilot, as his instructors believed he was too clumsy to make the grade as a fighter pilot. During the late 1930s he commanded the [[Provost (military police)|Provost Company]] of the [[56th (London) Division]] of the [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]]. From 1940 to 1942 he commanded the Military Police contingent of the [[Coats Mission]] tasked with evacuating [[King George VI]], [[Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother|Queen Elizabeth]] and their immediate family from London in the event of German invasion.{{cite book |title=Second to None: The History of the Coldstream Guards 1650 – 2000 |page=488 |author=Julian Paget |publisher=Casemate Publishers |year=2000 |isbn=1783379391}} On 23 January 1943 he was transferred from the [[Royal Military Police|Corps of Military Police]] to the [[General Service Corps|General List]].{{London Gazette |issue=35872 |date=22 January 1943 |page=435 |supp=y}} On 16 December 1945, having attained the age limit of 60, Campbell relinquished his commission and was granted the honorary rank of [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]].{{London Gazette |issue=37454 |date=5 February 1946 |page=802 |supp=y}} ==Grand Prix career== Campbell competed in [[Grand Prix motor racing]], winning the 1927 and 1928 Grand Prix de Boulogne in France driving a [[Bugatti Type 35#Type 39|Bugatti T37A]].{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==Land speed record== Campbell broke the land speed record for the first time in 1924 at {{convert|146.16|mi/h|km/h|2|abbr=on}} at [[Pendine Sands]] near [[Carmarthen Bay]] in a [[Sunbeam 350HP|350HP V12 Sunbeam]], now on display at the [[National Motor Museum, Beaulieu]]. He broke nine [[land speed record]]s between 1924 and 1935, with three at [[Pendine Sands]] and five at [[Daytona Beach Road Course|Daytona Beach]]. His first two records were driving a racing car built by [[Sunbeam Motor Car Company|Sunbeam]]. On 4 February 1927 Campbell set the land speed record at [[Pendine Sands]], covering the Flying Kilometre (in an average of two runs) at {{convert|174.883|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and the Flying Mile in {{convert|174.224|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, in the [[Napier-Campbell Blue Bird]].''Motor Sport'', March 1927, p.282; ''Motor Sport'', September 1927, p.77; ''Thrust'', by Richard Noble (Bantam Books, 1999), p.401. He set his final land speed record at the [[Bonneville Salt Flats]] in [[Utah]] on 3 September 1935, and was the first person to drive an automobile over 300 mph, averaging {{convert|301.337|mph|km/h|3|abbr=on}} in two passes. ==Water speed records== Campbell developed and flotation-tested Blue Bird on Tilgate Lake, in [[Tilgate Park]], [[Crawley]].{{openplaque|2138}} He set the [[water speed record]] four times, his highest speed being {{convert|141.740|mi/h|km/h|3|abbr=on}} in the ''[[Blue Bird K4]]''. He set the record on 19 August 1939 on [[Coniston Water]], Cumbria, England. ==Politics== Campbell stood for Parliament without success at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1935|1935 general election]] in [[Deptford (UK Parliament constituency)|Deptford]] for the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], despite his links to the [[British Union of Fascists]].Julie V. Gottlieb, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/theme/96364?backToResults=%2Fsearch%2Frefine%2F%3FdocStart=1%26themesTabShow=true "British Union of Fascists (act. 1932–1940)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008 (Accessed 5 February 2014) Reportedly, he once adorned his car with a Fascist pennant of the [[London Volunteer Transport Service]], though there has been no photographic evidence to support this claim.Zander, Patrick Glenn. ''[https://smartech.gatech.edu/bitstream/handle/1853/28270/zander_patrick_g_200905_phd.pdf;jsessionid=0B2413EAA0AEC1D055ED3D422E59CDFA.smart2?sequence=1 Right Modern: Technology, Nation, and Britain's Extreme Right in the Interwar Period]''. Georgia Institute of Technology. May 2009. Page 99."Sir Malcolm Campbell Carries the Fastest Flag." ''Blackshirt''. 26 April 1935. Page 1.{{cite book|last=Dorril|first=Stephen|title=Blackshirt: Sir Oswald Mosley and British Fascism|publisher=Viking|location=London|year=2006 |ref=Dorril, Blackshirt|page=356}} ==Death== [[File:Grave of Malcolm Campbell.JPG|thumb|Campbell's grave at St Nicholas' Church in [[Chislehurst]].]] Campbell died after a series of strokes in 1948 in [[Reigate]], Surrey, aged 63 years.{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=0SjKo02SS07xqxW497z2Aw&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}} He was one of the few land speed record holders of his era to die of natural causes, as so many had died in crashes. His versatile racing on different vehicles made him internationally famous.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==Honours and awards== *In recognition of his service during World War I, Campbell was appointed a Member of the Military Division of the [[Order of the British Empire]] on 3 June 1919.{{London Gazette |issue=31378 |date=3 June 1919 |page=7029 |supp=y}} *In 1931 on his return from Daytona where he set a land speed record of {{convert|245.736|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, he was given a civic welcome and a [[Mansion House, London|Mansion House]] banquet in London, and was knighted at [[Buckingham Palace]] by [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] on 21 February 1931.{{London Gazette |issue=33692 |date=24 February 1931 |page=1283}} *He was awarded the [[Segrave Trophy]] in 1933 and 1939.{{Cite web | url = https://www.redbull.com/gb-en/10-great-winners-of-the-segrave-trophy | publisher = [[Red Bull]] | accessdate = 12 November 2017 | date = 12 November 2016 | first= Will | last= Gray | title = 10 great winners of the Segrave Trophy}}{{Cite web | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/42222621| title = Malcolm Campbell honoured | date = 27 January 1940| work = [[The Cairns Post]]| location = [[Cairns]] | accessdate = 12 November 2017 | page = 5}} *He was inducted into the [[International Motorsports Hall of Fame]] in 1990.{{Cite web |url=http://www.motorsportshalloffame.com/Hall-of-Fame-Members/Bio.aspx |title=Sir Malcolm Campbell - 1885-1948 |publisher=International Motorsports Hall of Fame |language=en-US |access-date=2018-09-01 |df=dmy-all}} *He was inducted into the [[Motorsports Hall of Fame of America]] in 1994.{{Cite web |url=http://www.mshf.com/hall-of-fame/inductees/sir-malcolm-campbell.html |title=Campbell, Sir Malcolm - At Large - 1994 |website=Motorsports Hall of Fame of America |language=en-gb |access-date=2018-09-01}} *In 2010 an [[English Heritage]] [[blue plaque]] commemorating Campbell and his son was installed at [[Canbury School]], [[Kingston Vale|Kingston Hill]], [[Kingston upon Thames]], where Donald was born in March 1921 and the Campbell family lived until late 1922.{{cite web |url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/blue-plaques/campbell-malcolm-donald |title=CAMPBELL, Donald (1921–1967) & CAMPBELL, Sir Malcolm (1885–1948) |publisher=[[English Heritage]] |accessdate=4 August 2012}} ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Malcolm Campbell}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051109071054/http://www.sirmalcolmcampbell.com/ www.SirMalcolmCampbell.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080513132732/http://www.sirmalcolmcampbell.com/sir35.html Newspaper articles and pic of 1935 land speed record] * [http://www.racingcampbells.com www.racingcampbells.com – dedicated to the memory of Campbell and his son Donald] * [http://www.bluebird-electric.net/sir_malcolm_campbell.htm Biography] * {{Find a Grave|7471108}} * [http://stars.library.ucf.edu/ahistoryofcentralfloridapodcast/28/ Leather Cap and Goggles] at [http://stars.library.ucf.edu/ahistoryofcentralfloridapodcast/ A History of Central Florida Podcast] * {{PM20|FID=pe/002935}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Campbell, Malcolm}} [[Category:Land Statistics: Airport website,{{cite web | url=http://www.aicm.com.mx/categoria/estadisticas | title=AICM Statistics (in Spanish) | publisher=AICM }} }} '''Mexico City International Airport''' ({{lang-es|link=yes|Aeropuerto Internacional de la Ciudad de México, AICM}}); officially ''Aeropuerto Internacional Benito Juárez'' ('''Benito Juárez International Airport''') {{Airport codes|MEX|MMMX}} is an [[international airport]] that serves [[Greater Mexico City]]. It is [[List of the busiest airports in Mexico|Mexico]]'s and [[List of busiest airports in Latin America by passenger traffic|Latin America]]'s busiest airport by passenger traffic and aircraft movements. The airport sustains 35,000 jobs directly and around 15,000 indirectly in the immediate area.{{cite web |url=http://www.ecquants.com/2012_MEX.aspx |title=Benito Juárez International airport - Economic and social impacts |publisher=Ecquants |accessdate=September 7, 2013}} The airport is owned by Grupo Aeroportuario de la Ciudad de México and operated by [[Aeropuertos y Servicios Auxiliares]], the [[government-owned corporation]], which also operates 22 other airports throughout Mexico. {{cite web |url = http://www.asa.gob.mx/swb/ASA/Aeropuertos_red_ASA |title = ASA's airport network (In Spanish) |publisher = ASA |date = July 2014 |accessdate = 2014-07-28 |format = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140726181541/http://www.asa.gob.mx/swb/ASA/Aeropuertos_red_ASA |archivedate = July 26, 2014 |df = mdy-all }} In recent years [[Lic. Adolfo López Mateos International Airport|Toluca Airport]] has become an alternate airport.{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/ciudad-metropoli/2015/impreso/toluca-busca-ser-la-8216tercera-pista-8217-del-aicm-129350.html|title=TLC and alternate airport for Mexico City (In Spanish)|publisher=El Universal|accessdate=March 29, 2015}} This [[hot and high]] airport is served by 30 domestic and international passenger airlines and 17 cargo carriers. As the main hub for Mexico's largest airline [[Aeroméxico]] (with [[Aeroméxico Connect]]), the airport has become a [[SkyTeam]] hub. It is also a hub for [[Aeromar]], [[Interjet]], [[Volaris]], and a focus city for [[VivaAerobus]]. On a typical day, more than 100,000 passengers pass through the airport to and from more than 100 destinations on four continents. In 2017, the airport handled 44,732,418 passengers, a 7.2% increase compared to 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.aicm.com.mx/acercadelaicm/archivos/files/Estadisticas/Estadisticas2017_En.pdf|title=Statistics Mexico City airport|publisher=Mexico City International Airport|accessdate=January 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114021902/https://www.aicm.com.mx/acercadelaicm/archivos/files/Estadisticas/Estadisticas2017_En.pdf|archive-date=January 14, 2018|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Operating near the limits of its capacity,{{cite news|title=Canaero to propose plan to ease Mexico City Airport saturation |first1=Juan José |last1=Lagorio |publisher=BN Americas |date=February 14, 2014 |url=http://www.bnamericas.com/news/privatization/canaero-to-propose-plan-to-ease-mexico-city-airport-saturation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329141123/https://www.bnamericas.com/news/privatization/canaero-to-propose-plan-to-ease-mexico-city-airport-saturation |archivedate=March 29, 2015 |df=mdy }}  calls for [[New International Airport for Mexico City|replacing the airport]] were announced in September 2014, with the proposed location to be built {{convert|16|km|mi}} north-northeast of the current airport, east of [[Ecatepec]].{{cite web|url=http://www.presidencia.gob.mx/nuevo-aeropuerto-internacional-de-la-ciudad-de-mexico/ |title=New Mexico City International Airport (In Spanish) |publisher=Presidency of the Republic |accessdate=September 7, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906224114/http://www.presidencia.gob.mx/nuevo-aeropuerto-internacional-de-la-ciudad-de-mexico/ |archivedate=September 6, 2014 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Mexico unveils Norman Foster design for new international airport |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date={{Date|2014-9-3|dmy}} |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/03/mexico-airport-norman-foster-design |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906222955/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/03/mexico-airport-norman-foster-design |archivedate=September 6, 2014 |df=mdy }}{{nbsp}} However, after a public plebiscite, the project was cancelled.[http://time.com/5438633/mexico-referendum-airport-rejected/] ==Location== Located at the neighbourhood of Peñón de los Baños within [[Venustiano Carranza, D.F.|Venustiano Carranza]], one of the sixteen boroughs into which [[Mexico City]] is divided, the airport is {{Convert|5|km|abbr=on}} east from [[Historic center of Mexico City|Downtown Mexico City]] and is surrounded by the built-up areas of [[Gustavo A. Madero, D.F.|Gustavo A. Madero]] to the north and [[Venustiano Carranza, D.F.|Venustiano Carranza]] to the west, south and east. As the airport is located on the east side of Mexico City and its runways run southwest-northeast, an airliner's landing approach is usually directly over the conurbation of Mexico City when the wind is from the northeast. Therefore, there is an important overflying problem and noise pollution.{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/2575234/The_dark_side_of_aeromobilities_Unplanned_airport_planning_in_Mexico_City|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140908164515/http://www.academia.edu/2575234/The_dark_side_of_aeromobilities_Unplanned_airport_planning_in_Mexico_City|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 8, 2014|title=Unplanned airport planning in Mexico City|publisher=Academia Education|accessdate=September 8, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://mexico.quadratin.com.mx/Se-quejan-vecinos-de-Interlomas-por-ruido-de-aviones/|title=Disgruntled neighbors by noise pollution in Mexico City|publisher=Quadratin|accessdate=September 8, 2014}} ==History== ===Origins=== [[File:Vuelo inaugural Iberia Madrid - México (1950).jpg|thumb|left|Inauguration of Iberia's Mexico City-Madrid route, March 1, 1950]] The original site, known as Llanos de Balbuena, had been used for aeronautical activities since 1910, when Alberto Braniff became the first to fly an aeroplane in Mexico, and in Latin America.{{cite web|url=http://sandiegoairandspace.org/exhibits/mexican_american_exhibit/|title=Mexican-americans in aviation online exhibition|publisher=San Diego Air & Space Museum|accessdate=September 7, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/the_americas/summary/v067/67.3.ganson.html|title=Conquistador of the Sky: A History of Aviation in Latin America|publisher=Project MUSE|accessdate=September 7, 2014}} The flight was onboard of a [[Voisin 1907 biplane|Voisin]] biplane. On November 30, 1911, President [[Francisco I. Madero]], was the first head of State in the world to fly onboard of a [[Deperdussin]] airplane piloted by Geo M. Dyott of Moisant International.{{cite web|url=http://thecatalist.org/2010/01/570/|title=Mexico's 100 years of flying taking off to new heights!|publisher=The Catalist|accessdate=September 7, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mexconnect.com/articles/1171-did-you-know-the-world-s-first-aerial-bombing-the-battle-of-topolobampo-mexico|title=A brief Mexican History aviation|publisher=Mexconnect|accessdate=September 7, 2014}} In 1915 the airport first opened as Balbuena Military Airport with five runways. Construction of a small civilian airport began in 1928. The first landing was on November 5, 1928, and regular service started in 1929, but was officially inaugurated on May 15, 1931. On July 8, 1943, the Official Gazette of the Federation published a decree that acknowledged Mexico City's Central Airport as an international airport, capable of managing international arrivals and departures of passengers and aircraft. Its first international route was to [[Los Angeles International Airport]] operated by [[Mexicana de Aviación|Mexicana]]. Construction of Runway 05D-23I started six years later, as well as new facilities such as a platform, a terminal building, a control tower and offices for the authorities. The runway started its operations in 1951. On November 19, 1952, President [[Miguel Alemán Valdés|Miguel Alemán]] opened the passenger terminal, which later became Terminal 1.{{cite web|url=http://contenido.com.mx/2013/11/un-ano-mas-del-aicm/|title=One more year of Mexico City International Airport (In Spanish)|publisher=Contenido|accessdate=September 7, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907005210/http://contenido.com.mx/2013/11/un-ano-mas-del-aicm/|archivedate=September 7, 2014|df=mdy-all}} In 1956 the airport had four runways in service: 05L-23R (2,720m long, 40m wide), 05R-23L (3,000m long, 45m wide), with electric lights for night-time service; 13-31 (2,300m long, 40m wide) which had been built to relieve 14-32, to which residential areas had encroached too closely; and 5 Auxiliar (759m long).{{Cite web |url=http://www.aicm.com.mx/acercadelaicm/Archivos/BREVEHISTORIA2011.pdf |title="Breve Historia del Aeropuerto Internacional de la Ciudad de México", Mexico City International Airport |access-date=September 6, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906085020/http://www.aicm.com.mx/acercadelaicm/Archivos/BREVEHISTORIA2011.pdf |archive-date=September 6, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ===1960s–1990s=== [[File:JFK exiting Air Force One.jpg|thumb|President and Mrs. Kennedy disembark Air Force One, June 29, 1962]] On December 2, 1963, Walter C. Buchanan, former director of the Transport and Communications Department (SCT), changed the airport's name "Aeropuerto Central" (Central Airport) to "Aeropuerto Internacional de la Ciudad de México" (Mexico City International Airport).{{cite web |url=http://www.colegiodepilotos.org/nosotros/la-aviaci%C3%B3n-en-m%C3%A9xico/ |title=Historia de la aviación en México (in Spanish) |publisher=Colegio de Pilotos de México |accessdate=2016-01-26 |format= }} In the 1970s, president [[Luis Echeverría]] closed the two remaining shorter runways (13/31 and 5 Auxiliar); on the land of 13-31 a social housing complex was built, Unidad Fiviport.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2cRjAAAAMAAJ|title=Obras|publisher=|accessdate=June 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://mexdfmagazine.com/2013/02/22/a-new-airport-for-mexico-city/|title=A New Airport for Mexico City?|work=MexDFmagazine|accessdate=June 4, 2015}}Historic photo at [http://www.flyapm.com/foro/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=139 FlyAPM site] leaving the two parallel runways. In 1980, the terminal was expanded to double its capacity, using a single large terminal rather than multiple terminals as in other airports. Ten years later in 1990, the mixed domestic/international gates were separated to increase the terminal's functionality, along with the separation of domestic and international check-in halls. {{citation needed|date=December 2015}} On November 24, 1978, the "Mexico" Control Tower began its operations; it has been in service since then. The AICM has continually improved its infrastructure. On August 15, 1979, and after about a year of remodeling works, the terminal building reopened to the public; the airport continued its operations during the renovation, which improved passenger transit with better space distribution in walkways and rooms.{{cite web |url=https://www.academia.edu/13087948/Sistema_Aeroportuario_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico |title=Sistema Aeroportuario de la Ciudad de México (in Spanish) |publisher=Esquinca, Rosique |date=May 25, 2013 |accessdate=2016-02-03 }} Due to constant growth in demand of both passengers and operations, on January 13, 1994, the Official Gazette of the Federation, published a presidential decree that prohibited general aviation operations in the AICM, which were moved to [[Lic. Adolfo López Mateos International Airport|Toluca International Airport]] in order to clear air traffic in the capital's airport.{{cite web |url=http://dof.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=4659102&fecha=13/01/1994 |title=DECRETO que establece el cierre del Aeropuerto Internacional de la Ciudad de México Benito Juárez (in Spanish) |publisher=Diario Oficial de la Federación |date=January 13, 1994 |accessdate=2016-02-03 }} Renovations to the AICM continued and on April 11, 1994, a new International Terminal building was ready and operational. It was built by a private contractor according to a co-investment agreement with Airports and Auxiliary Services. In 2001, in order to further improve service to passengers, construction for Module XI started. This Module permitted eight new contact positions in the Airport Terminal, capable of receiving eight regular airplanes, two wide-body, or four narrow-body aircraft.{{cite web |url=http://archivo.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/11622.html |title=Iniciaría en febrero la ampliación del AICM (in Spanish) |publisher=El Universal |date=January 3, 2000 |accessdate=2016-02-03 }} ===2003–2007 expansion=== Because of the increasing traffic, president [[Vicente Fox]] announced the construction of a new, larger airport on {{Convert|5000|ha|abbr=on}} in the municipalities of [[Texcoco, Mexico State|Texcoco]] and [[San Salvador Atenco]], but when [[Community Front in Defense of Land|local violent protests]] took place in 2002, the new airport was cancelled.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/03/international/americas/03MEXI.html|title=Mexico drops planned airport after protests from peasants|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=September 7, 2014}} Instead, to respond to the growing demand and aiming to position the AICM as one of the greatest in terms of quality, services, security, and operational functionality, on May 30, 2003, the Federal Government announced an update: an extension to the air terminal in order to widen its service capacity from 20 million to 32 million passengers a year. This program was part of the Metropolitan Airport System, promoted by the Federal Administration. The Communications and Transportation Ministry (SCT), Aeropuertos y Servicios Auxiliares (ASA) and AICM performed expansion and remodeling work on Terminal 1, over a surface area of {{convert|90000|m2}}; 48,000 of which were new construction and 42,000 of which were remodeled. The renovations include new airline counters, commercial spaces and an elevator for people with disabilities, which improved the flow of passengers with domestic destinations. Among other works performed in the international area, a long-distance bus terminal was built with connections to Puebla, Cuernavaca, Pachuca, Toluca, Querétaro and Orizaba. The new bus station has access to a food court and the international arrivals and departures area, as well as a pedestrian bridge that connects to "The Peñón de los Baños" neighborhood. The airport was formally named after the 19th-century president [[Benito Juárez]] in 2006.{{cite web|title=Decretará Fox que el AICM se denomine Benito Juárez |first1=Triunfo |last1=Elizalde |first2=Rosa Elvira |last2=Vargas |trans-title=President Vicente Fox decrees official name for Mexico City Airport |language=Spanish |publisher=La Jornada |date={{Date|2006-10-5|mdy}} |url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2006/10/05/index.php?section=politica&article=024n1pol |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908232128/https://www.jornada.unam.mx/2006/10/05/index.php?section=politica&article=024n1pol |archivedate=September 8, 2014 |df=mdy }}  On November 15, 2007, Terminal 2 was opened, significantly increasing the airport's capacity. All SkyTeam members moved their operations to the new terminal, except [[Air France]] and [[KLM]]. It was officially inaugurated in March 2008, once the new road accesses and taxiways were finished. Terminal 2 increased the airport's contact positions by 40% and the operational capacity by 15%. The terminal was inaugurated by former President [[Felipe Calderón Hinojosa]].{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/travel/flights/2007-11-16-mexico-city-airport_N.htm|title=Mexico City inaugurates new airport terminal|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=September 7, 2014}} ==Lack of capacity and slot restriction== {{Multiple image||align=right||image1=Aerial View of Mexico City Airport on 3.21.11.jpg|thumb|caption1=The airport as seen from an aircraft in 2011.||width1=197||image2=Benitojuarezarptaerial.jpg|thumb|caption2=aerial view of the airport before the construction of Terminal 2.||width2=170}} The airport has suffered from a lack of capacity due to restrictions on expansion, since it is located in a densely populated area. In 2014, Mexican authorities established and declared a maximum capacity of 61 operations per hour with a total of 16 rush hours (7:00 –22:59).{{cite web |url=http://dof.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=5361802&fecha=29/09/2014 |title=DECLARATORIA de saturación en el campo aéreo del Aeropuerto Internacional de la Ciudad de México (in Spanish) |publisher=Diario Oficial de la Federación |date=2014-09-29 |accessdate=2016-01-26 |format= }} Another issue with the airport is the limitation that its two runways provide, since they are used at 97.3% of their maximum capacity, leaving a very short room for new operations into the airport. Only government, military, commercial, and specially authorised aircraft are allowed to land at the airport. Private aircraft must use alternate airports, such as [[Lic. Adolfo López Mateos International Airport]] in [[Toluca]], [[General Mariano Matamoros Airport]] in [[Cuernavaca]], or [[Hermanos Serdán International Airport]] in [[Puebla]]. ==Failed attempt to replace the airport== {{Main article|New Mexico City international airport}} [[File:FernandoRomero01.jpeg|thumb|Architect [[Fernando Romero]] and the scale model of the New Mexico City airport.]] The construction of a [[new Mexico City international airport]] was announced by Mexican president [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] on September 2, 2014,{{cite web|title=New Mexico City International Airport |work=CAPA Centre for Aviation |url=http://centreforaviation.com/profiles/newairports/new-mexico-city-international-airport |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906201454/https://centreforaviation.com/profiles/newairports/new-mexico-city-international-airport |archivedate=September 6, 2014 |df=mdy }}  who said that it would be ''emblemático'', or a national symbol. The new airport will replace the current Mexico City International Airport, which is at capacity. It is to have one large terminal of {{convert|6000000|ft2|m2}} and six runways: two that are each {{convert|4.5|km|mi ft}} long and four that are each {{convert|4|km|mi ft}} long. The architects are Sir [[Norman Foster]] and [[Fernando Romero]], son-in-law of billionaire [[Carlos Slim]] and architect of the [[Soumaya Museum]].{{cite news|title=UPDATE 1-Mexico eyes foreign builder, local partners for $9 bln airport |first1=Veronica |last1=Gomez |first2=Gabriel |last2=Stargardter |work=[[Reuters]] |date={{Date|2014-9-4|mdy}} |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/04/mexico-airport-idUSL1N0R51U720140904 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905114617/https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/04/mexico-airport-idUSL1N0R51U720140904 |archivedate=September 5, 2014 |df=mdy }} {{cite news|title=Mexico to open new mega airport in 2018 |first=Rainer |last=Uphoff |location=[[Madrid]] |work=[[Flightglobal]] |date={{Date|2014-9-4|mdy}} |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/mexico-to-open-new-mega-airport-in-2018-403347/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905115031/https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/mexico-to-open-new-mega-airport-in-2018-403347/ |archivedate=September 5, 2014 |df=mdy }}  Construction will take eight years and depending on the source, is estimated to cost 120 or 169 billion [[Mexican pesos]], about 9–13 billion U.S. dollars. It will be built on land already owned by the federal government in the ''Zona Federal del Lago de Texcoco'', between [[Ecatepec]] and [[San Salvador Atenco|Atenco]] in the [[State of Mexico]], about 10 km northeast of the current airport.[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2014/0903/Ready-for-landing-Mexico-City-airport-expansion-could-make-it-one-of-largest-in-world "Ready for landing: Mexico City airport expansion could make it one of largest in world", ''Christian Science Monitor'', 2014-09-03]{{cite news|title= Mexico Plans New $9.2 Billion Airport|first= David|last= Luhnow|newspaper= [[The Wall Street Journal]]|date= {{Date|2014-9-2|mdy}}|url= https://online.wsj.com/articles/mexico-plans-new-9-2-billion-airport-1409676782}} {{paywall}} The terminal is to be sustainable, aiming for a LEED Platinum certification.{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/mexico-citys-new-mega-airport-will-collect-its-own-ener-1630253952|title=Mexico City's New Mega-Airport Will Collect Its Own Energy and Water|author=Alissa Walker|publisher=Gawker Media|work=Gizmodo|accessdate=June 4, 2015}} The project, however, was cancelled on October 30, 2018 after voters voted against a referendum related to the airport.[http://time.com/5438633/mexico-referendum-airport-rejected/] ==Terminals and facilities== {{Multiple image||align=right||image1=Mexico City Previous Terminal Layout.JPG|thumb|caption1=Terminal layout before T2.||width1=190||image2=Nuevas Terminales AICM.jpg|thumb|caption2=Terminal layout after T2 was built.||width2=190}} [[File:MEX T2.jpg|thumb|External facade of Terminal 2.]] [[File:Aeropuerto Internacional de la Ciudad de México - Terminal 2 - Área de Salidas.jpg|thumb|Terminal 2 - Departures waiting area.]] [[File:Wikimania Mexico City 20.07.2015 08-55-44.JPG|thumb|Terminal 2 - Display screens.]] [[File:MEX T2 check in.jpg|thumb|Terminal 2 - Hall L3 Check-in counters.]] [[File:MMMXT2.jpg|thumb|Central corridor at T2.]] ===Terminals=== {{Prose|Section|date=May 2016}} Mexico City International Airport has two passenger terminals. Terminal 1 is separated from Terminal 2 by the runways. ====Terminal 1==== * Opened in 1958; expanded in 1970, 1989, 1998, 2000 and 2004 * Overall terminal surface: {{Convert|542000|m2|abbr=on}} * Contact positions: 33 ** Two contact positions equipped for the [[Airbus A380]] * Remote positions: 17 (34 Before New T2 was built) * Number of jetways: 33 * Number of airside halls: 10 * Number of landside (check-in) halls: 9 * Number of mobile-lounges: 11 * Hotel service: ** 600 room [[Camino Real Hotels|Camino Real]] ** 288 room [[Courtyard by Marriott]] ** 327 room [[Fiesta Inn]] (Located across from Terminal 1) ** 110 room [[Hilton Hotels & Resorts|Hilton]] * Parking service: 3,100 vehicles (Domestic), 2,400 vehicles (International) * Space per passenger in T1: {{Convert|17|m2|abbr=on}} * Number of baggage claim carousels: 22 ====Terminal 2==== * Opened in 2007 * Overall terminal surface: {{Convert|288000|m2|abbr=on}} * Contact positions: 23 * Remote positions: 18 (Aeromar and Aeroméxico Connect) * Number of jetways: 23 * Number of airside halls: 2 (Domestic, International) * Number of landside (check-in) halls: 3 (L1, L2, L3) * Hotel service: ** 287 room [[NH Hoteles|NH]] * Parking service: 3,000 vehicles * Space per passenger in T2: {{Convert|22|m2|abbr=on}} * Number of baggage claim carousels: 15) * Platform surface: {{Convert|426000|m2|abbr=on}} * Inter-terminal [[Aerotrén]] capacity: 7,800 daily passengers Terminal 2 was built over a surface area of 242,666.55m² and has modern security systems, in accordance with international standards including a passenger traffic separation systems. The new facility will help AICM increase its capacity to 32 million passengers per year. Air operations in the new facilities began on November 15, 2007, with flights by [[Aeromar]] and [[Delta Air Lines]], and later [[AeroMéxico]], [[Copa Airlines|Copa]], [[LAN Airlines|LAN]] and [[Continental Airlines]]. Terminal 2 was formally inaugurated by former Presidente [[Felipe Calderón Hinojosa]] on March 26, 2008. These projects were done without affecting airplane takeoffs and landings, and will help Mexico City International Airport offer better services, and respond to the growing demand of passengers and operations in the coming years. Terminal 2 now houses all Aeroméxico flights out of the airport, becoming the airline's main distribution center. Although the terminal was intended to be served by all-SkyTeam member airlines, Air France and KLM decided to remain at Terminal 1. ==Other facilities== [[Aeropuertos y Servicios Auxiliares]], a government-owned corporation that operates airports in Mexico, has its headquarters on the airport property.,{{cite web|url=http://www.asa.gob.mx|title=ASA's address|publisher=Aeropuertos y Servicios Auxiliares|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} [[Aeropuertos y Servicios Auxiliares]].Retrieved on December 20, 2011. "Av.602 No.161 Col.Zona Federal Aeropuerto Internacional Ciudad de México Delegación Venustiano Carranza, C.P.15620, México D.F." The Aeromar headquarters are located in Hangar 7 in Zone D of the General Aviation Terminal of the airport."Directory: World Airlines." ''[[Flight International]]''. March 16–22, 2004. [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/2004/2004-09%20-%200052.html?search=Aeromar 50]. "Hangar 7, Zona "D", Terminal de Aviacion General, Col Federal, Mexico DF, 15620, Mexico"{{cite web|url=http://www.aeromar.com.mx/contacto/|title=Aeromar headquarters and Customer Service Center|publisher=Aeromar|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} [[Aviacsa]] had its headquarters in Hangar 1 in Zone C, but ceased operations on May 4, 2011."[https://web.archive.org/web/20041209104841/http://www.aviacsa.com/WEB/reservaciones/diractual.html Directorio]." Aviacsa. Consulted on January 23, 2011. "DIRECCIÓN COMERCIAL Hangar 1, Zona "C", Col. Aviación Gral. [...] Aeropuerto Int. de la Cd. de México. C.P. 15520 (in Spanish)" ==Airlines and destinations== The airport connects 52 domestic and 50 international destinations in Latin America, North America, Europe and Asia. [[Aeromexico]] serves the largest number of cities from any Latin American hub (80), 46 domestic and 34 international.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/aeromexico-the-airline-serving-the-largest-number-of-cities-from-a-hub-in-latin-america-300158276.html|title=Aeromexico, The Airline Serving The Largest Number Of Cities From A Hub In Latin America|first=|last=Aeromexico|website=www.prnewswire.com}} Most prominent foreign airlines are [[United Airlines]], [[American Airlines]], [[Delta Air Lines]] and [[Avianca Holdings]]. [[Aeroméxico]]/[[Aeroméxico Connect]] operates the most departures from the airport followed by [[Interjet]], [[Volaris]], and [[Aeromar]]. Aeroméxico also operates to the most destinations followed by Interjet. ===Passenger=== [[File:15-07-21-Flug-MEX-CDG-RalfR-N3S 9763.jpg|thumb|right|Terminal 2 - [[Aeroméxico]] and [[Delta Air Lines|Delta]] aircraft parked at North Concourse. Aeroméxico is the largest carrier operating at Benito Juárez Airport.]] [[File:PH-BFI Boeing B.747 KLM (7629304750).jpg|thumb|KLM Boeing 747 arriving from Schiphol.]] [[File:G-CIVT Boeing B.747 British Airways (7629453876).jpg|thumb|British Airways Boeing 747-400 landing from Heathrow Airport.]] [[File:EC-JCY Airbus A.340 Iberia (7630383254).jpg|thumb|Iberia [[Airbus A340|Airbus A340-600]] taxiing at the airport.]] [[File:HP-1534CMP Boeing B.737 Copa Airlines (7630243552).jpg|thumb|Copa Airlines [[Boeing 737|Boeing 737-800]] taking off to Panama City.]] [[File:N963AN Boeing B.737 American Airlines (7630381328).jpg|thumb|American Airlines [[Boeing 737|Boeing 737-800]]. It registered a year-to-year increase of 7.2%. In terms of international passengers, it was the second busiest airport in Latin America with '''15,753,355''' passengers, behind [[Cancún International Airport|Cancún]]{{cite web|url=http://asur.com.mx/en/investor-relations/passenger-traffic.html|title=ASUR Passenger Traffic}} and the second busiest in Mexico after [[Cancún International Airport|Cancún]]. The airport is the busiest in Latin America by aircraft movements with 24% more operations than [[El Dorado International Airport|Bogotá-El Dorado]]{{cite web|url=http://www.aerocivil.gov.co/AAeronautica/Estadisticas/TAereo/EOperacionales/BolPubAnte/Paginas/BolMensTraficoAerop.aspx|title=Bogota airport statistics|publisher=Bogota International Airport|accessdate=February 3, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151027053845/http://www.aerocivil.gov.co/AAeronautica/Estadisticas/TAereo/EOperacionales/BolPubAnte/Paginas/BolMensTraficoAerop.aspx|archivedate=October 27, 2015|df=mdy-all}} and 44.65% more than [[São Paulo–Guarulhos International Airport|São Paulo-Guarulhos]].{{cite web|url=https://www.gru.com.br/pt/institucional/sobre-gru-airport/informacoes-operacionais|title=Guarulhos Airport Statistics (in Portuguese)|publisher=Guarulhos International Airport|accessdate=January 12, 2017}} It is the 15th busiest airport in the world in terms of aircraft departures.http://www.icao.int/sustainability/Documents/MonthlyMonitor-2016/MonthlyMonitor_February2016.pdf In 2016, the airport handled '''448,147''' aircraft operations, an average of '''1,227''' operations per day. Regarding cargo, the airport is also the busiest in the country and the second busiest in Latin America, after [[El Dorado International Airport]] in [[Bogotá]]. During 2017, it moved over '''537,262.69''' tons, an annual increase of 11.13%. The net growth of 53,000 tons was the biggest in the region. {| style="border:solid 1px #aaa;" cellpadding="10" cellspacing="0" |+'''Mexico City Airport Passengers – 1990–2017 (millions)''' |- | ImageSize = width:auto height:250 barincrement:29 PlotArea = left:30 bottom:15 top:10 right:15 AlignBars = justify Period = from:10 till:50 TimeAxis = orientation:vertical Colors = id:gray value:gray(0.5) id:line1 value:gray(0.9) id:line2 value:gray(0.7) ScaleMajor = start:10 increment:2 gridcolor:line2 ScaleMinor = start:10 increment:1 gridcolor:line1 PlotData= color:blue width:20 bar:1990 from:start till:12.152 bar:1991 from:start till:13.002 bar:1992 from:start till:15.442 bar:1993 from:start till:16.342 bar:1994 from:start till:18.889 bar:1995 from:start till:15.854 bar:1996 from:start till:16.265 bar:1997 from:start till:17.833 bar:1998 from:start till:18.946 bar:1999 from:start till:20.454 bar:2000 from:start till:21.043 bar:2001 from:start till:20.599 bar:2002 from:start till:20.521 bar:2003 from:start till:21.693 bar:2004 from:start till:22.940 bar:2005 from:start till:24.115 bar:2006 from:start till:24.727 bar:2007 from:start till:25.881 bar:2008 from:start till:26.210 bar:2009 from:start till:24.243 bar:2010 from:start till:24.130 bar:2011 from:start till:26.368 bar:2012 from:start till:29.491 bar:2013 from:start till:31.534 bar:2014 from:start till:34.255 bar:2015 from:start till:38.433 bar:2016 from:start till:41.710 color:darkblue bar:2017 from:start till:44.732 |- |Updated: January 12, 2018. |}
